json-formatter.summary: Learn how to format, validate, and debug JSON data effectively

what-is-json.title: What is JSON?
what-is-json.content:
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format. It's easy for humans to read and write, and easy for machines to parse and generate.

JSON is built on two structures:
‚Ä¢ A collection of name/value pairs (like an object or dictionary)
‚Ä¢ An ordered list of values (like an array)

JSON is language-independent but uses conventions familiar to programmers of C-family languages.

common-errors.title: Common JSON Errors and How to Fix Them
common-errors.content:
These are the most common JSON syntax errors developers encounter:

1. Missing quotes around keys - JSON requires all keys to be strings in double quotes
2. Trailing commas - Unlike JavaScript, JSON doesn't allow trailing commas
3. Single quotes - JSON only accepts double quotes for strings
4. Unescaped characters - Special characters like newlines and tabs must be escaped
5. Comments - JSON doesn't support comments (use JSONC for that)

how-to-use.title: How to Use the JSON Formatter
how-to-use.content:
Using our JSON Formatter is simple:

1. Paste your JSON in the input area on the left
2. The formatted result appears automatically on the right
3. Choose your preferred indentation (2 spaces, 4 spaces, or tab)
4. Use the Minify button to compress JSON for production
5. Click Copy to copy the result to your clipboard

The tool validates your JSON in real-time and highlights any syntax errors with their exact location.

advanced-features.title: Advanced Features
advanced-features.content:
Beyond basic formatting, our tool offers:

‚Ä¢ Minification - Remove all whitespace to reduce file size
‚Ä¢ Validation - Real-time syntax checking with error messages
‚Ä¢ Line numbers - Easy navigation in large JSON files
‚Ä¢ Dark mode - Comfortable viewing in low-light environments
‚Ä¢ No data transmission - All processing happens in your browser

api-debugging.title: Real-World Example: API Debugging
api-debugging.content:
When debugging API responses, formatted JSON is essential:

1. Copy the raw API response from your browser's Network tab
2. Paste it into the formatter to see the structure clearly
3. Identify nested objects, arrays, and data types
4. Find the specific fields you need for your application

This workflow saves hours when working with complex APIs and helps you understand data structures quickly.

jwt-decoder.summary: Understand JWT tokens, decode them safely, and debug authentication issues

what-is-jwt.title: What is a JWT?
what-is-jwt.content:
JWT (JSON Web Token) is an open standard for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object.

JWTs are commonly used for:
‚Ä¢ Authentication - Proving user identity
‚Ä¢ Authorization - Granting access to resources
‚Ä¢ Information exchange - Securely transmitting data

A JWT is a string with three parts separated by dots: header.payload.signature

jwt-structure.title: JWT Structure Explained
jwt-structure.content:
Every JWT has three parts:

1. Header - Contains the token type (JWT) and signing algorithm (like HS256 or RS256)

2. Payload - Contains the claims (statements about the user and additional data)

3. Signature - Verifies the token hasn't been tampered with

Both header and payload are Base64Url encoded JSON objects.

common-claims.title: Common JWT Claims
common-claims.content:
Standard claims you'll encounter:

‚Ä¢ iss (Issuer) - Who created the token
‚Ä¢ sub (Subject) - Who the token identifies (usually user ID)
‚Ä¢ aud (Audience) - Who the token is intended for
‚Ä¢ exp (Expiration) - When the token expires (Unix timestamp)
‚Ä¢ iat (Issued At) - When the token was created
‚Ä¢ nbf (Not Before) - Token not valid before this time
‚Ä¢ jti (JWT ID) - Unique identifier for the token

Custom claims can contain any application-specific data.

debugging-expired.title: Debugging Expired Tokens
debugging-expired.content:
Token expiration is a common issue. Here's how to debug:

1. Decode the token to view the payload
2. Find the 'exp' claim (expiration timestamp)
3. Convert the timestamp to a readable date
4. Compare with the current time

Our decoder shows expiration status automatically - look for the red 'Expired' or green 'Valid' badge.

Common fixes:
‚Ä¢ Refresh the token before it expires
‚Ä¢ Check server/client time synchronization
‚Ä¢ Verify token lifetime settings in your auth server

security-tips.title: JWT Security Best Practices
security-tips.content:
Keep your JWTs secure:

1. Never store sensitive data in the payload - It's encoded, not encrypted
2. Use short expiration times - Refresh tokens instead of long-lived access tokens
3. Validate tokens server-side - Never trust client-side validation alone
4. Use HTTPS - Prevent token interception
5. Store tokens securely - HttpOnly cookies are safer than localStorage
6. Implement token revocation - For logout and security events

Remember: JWTs are decoded, not decrypted. Anyone can read the payload!

base64-converter.summary: Master Base64 encoding for images, files, and data transmission

what-is-base64.title: What is Base64?
what-is-base64.content:
Base64 is a binary-to-text encoding scheme that converts binary data into ASCII characters.

Why Base64 exists:
‚Ä¢ Safely transmit binary data over text-only channels (like email)
‚Ä¢ Embed binary data in text formats (like JSON or XML)
‚Ä¢ Include images directly in HTML/CSS without separate files

Base64 uses 64 characters: A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, and / (with = for padding).

encoding-images.title: Encoding Images for Web
encoding-images.content:
Base64-encoded images can be embedded directly in HTML or CSS:

Advantages:
‚Ä¢ Reduces HTTP requests
‚Ä¢ Works offline once loaded
‚Ä¢ Simple deployment (no separate image files)

Disadvantages:
‚Ä¢ ~33% larger than binary
‚Ä¢ No browser caching
‚Ä¢ Increases HTML/CSS file size

Best practice: Use Base64 for small images (icons, logos) under 10KB.

common-use-cases.title: Common Use Cases
common-use-cases.content:
Base64 is essential for:

1. Data URLs - Embedding resources in web pages
2. Email attachments - MIME encoding
3. API payloads - Sending binary data in JSON
4. Authentication - Basic auth headers (username:password)
5. Certificates - PEM format for SSL/TLS

Our tool handles text and files, generating proper data URLs automatically.

data-urls.title: Understanding Data URLs
data-urls.content:
Data URLs embed content directly in the URL:

Format: data:[mediatype][;base64],<data>

Components:
‚Ä¢ data: - The URL scheme
‚Ä¢ mediatype - MIME type (e.g., image/png, text/plain)
‚Ä¢ ;base64 - Indicates Base64 encoding
‚Ä¢ data - The actual encoded content

Data URLs work anywhere a regular URL works: img src, CSS url(), fetch(), and more.

size-considerations.title: Size and Performance
size-considerations.content:
Important considerations:

‚Ä¢ Base64 increases size by ~33% (3 bytes become 4 characters)
‚Ä¢ Large Base64 strings can slow page rendering
‚Ä¢ Browser decode limits vary (usually safe up to several MB)
‚Ä¢ Consider gzip compression for text-based formats

Rule of thumb:
‚Ä¢ Under 10KB: Base64 is usually beneficial
‚Ä¢ 10-50KB: Evaluate case by case
‚Ä¢ Over 50KB: Use regular file URLs instead

regex-tester.summary: Learn regular expressions with practical examples for validation and parsing

what-is-regex.title: What is Regex?
what-is-regex.content:
Regular expressions (regex) are patterns used to match character combinations in strings.

Regex is used for:
‚Ä¢ Validation - Check if input matches a pattern
‚Ä¢ Searching - Find text matching a pattern
‚Ä¢ Extraction - Pull specific data from strings
‚Ä¢ Replacement - Transform text based on patterns

While regex syntax looks cryptic at first, it's incredibly powerful once learned.

email-validation.title: Email Validation Pattern
email-validation.content:
Email validation is one of the most common regex use cases.

A basic email pattern checks for:
‚Ä¢ Username part (letters, numbers, dots, hyphens)
‚Ä¢ @ symbol
‚Ä¢ Domain name
‚Ä¢ TLD (top-level domain)

Note: Perfect email validation is actually impossible with regex alone. The best approach is a simple pattern plus sending a verification email.

phone-validation.title: Phone Number Patterns
phone-validation.content:
Phone numbers vary by country and format:

US formats to consider:
‚Ä¢ 123-456-7890 (dashed)
‚Ä¢ (123) 456-7890 (parentheses)
‚Ä¢ +1 123 456 7890 (international)

For international support, the E.164 format (+[country][number]) is most reliable.

Tip: Store phone numbers in a normalized format and display them formatted for the user's locale.

common-patterns.title: Common Regex Patterns
common-patterns.content:
Patterns every developer should know:

‚Ä¢ URL - Matches http/https URLs
‚Ä¢ IP Address - Validates IPv4 addresses
‚Ä¢ Date - Matches YYYY-MM-DD format
‚Ä¢ Hex Color - Matches #RGB or #RRGGBB
‚Ä¢ Password - Enforces complexity requirements

Our tool includes a library of these patterns for quick reference.

flags-modifiers.title: Regex Flags and Modifiers
flags-modifiers.content:
Flags change how the regex engine matches:

‚Ä¢ g (global) - Find all matches, not just the first
‚Ä¢ i (case-insensitive) - Ignore uppercase/lowercase
‚Ä¢ m (multiline) - ^ and $ match line beginnings/endings
‚Ä¢ s (dotall) - . matches newlines too
‚Ä¢ u (unicode) - Full Unicode support
‚Ä¢ y (sticky) - Match at exact position only

Combine flags as needed: /pattern/gi for global case-insensitive matching.

hash-generator.summary: Understand cryptographic hashes and when to use MD5, SHA-256, or SHA-512

what-is-hash.title: What is a Hash?
what-is-hash.content:
A hash function takes input of any size and produces a fixed-size output (the hash or digest).

Key properties:
‚Ä¢ Deterministic - Same input always produces same output
‚Ä¢ One-way - Cannot reverse a hash to get the original input
‚Ä¢ Collision-resistant - Different inputs rarely produce same hash
‚Ä¢ Avalanche effect - Small input changes create very different hashes

Hashes are fingerprints for data - unique identifiers for any content.

md5-vs-sha.title: MD5 vs SHA: Which to Use?
md5-vs-sha.content:
Choosing the right algorithm:

MD5 (128-bit):
‚Ä¢ Fast but cryptographically broken
‚Ä¢ OK for checksums, NOT for security
‚Ä¢ Collisions can be created intentionally

SHA-1 (160-bit):
‚Ä¢ Deprecated for security uses
‚Ä¢ Still seen in legacy systems

SHA-256 (256-bit):
‚Ä¢ Current standard for most uses
‚Ä¢ Good balance of security and speed

SHA-512 (512-bit):
‚Ä¢ Maximum security
‚Ä¢ Slightly slower, longer output

use-cases.title: Real-World Use Cases
use-cases.content:
Hashes are everywhere in software:

1. File integrity - Verify downloads haven't been corrupted
2. Password storage - Store hashes, not plain passwords (use bcrypt/argon2!)
3. Data deduplication - Identify duplicate files by hash
4. Git commits - SHA-1 identifies every commit
5. Blockchain - Chain of hashes ensures integrity

Important: For passwords, use specialized hashing (bcrypt, argon2) not raw SHA-256!

hash-verification.title: Verifying File Integrity
hash-verification.content:
Always verify important downloads:

1. Download the file
2. Get the expected hash from the official source
3. Calculate the hash of your downloaded file
4. Compare the two hashes

If they match exactly, the file hasn't been modified. Even one bit difference produces a completely different hash.

Our tool makes this easy - paste the expected hash and we'll tell you if it matches.

security-best-practices.title: Security Best Practices
security-best-practices.content:
Hash security guidelines:

‚Ä¢ Never use MD5 or SHA-1 for security purposes
‚Ä¢ Use SHA-256 or SHA-512 for data integrity
‚Ä¢ For passwords, use bcrypt, scrypt, or argon2 (with salt)
‚Ä¢ Store hashes, never plaintext
‚Ä¢ Use constant-time comparison to prevent timing attacks
‚Ä¢ Consider HMAC when you need authentication

Remember: Hashes verify integrity, not confidentiality. Use encryption if data must stay secret.

unix-timestamp.summary: Convert between Unix timestamps and human-readable dates

what-is-unix-timestamp.title: What is a Unix Timestamp?
what-is-unix-timestamp.content:
A Unix timestamp (also called Epoch time) is the number of seconds that have elapsed since January 1, 1970, at 00:00:00 UTC.

Why use timestamps?
‚Ä¢ Language-independent - Same value worldwide
‚Ä¢ Easy to compare - Simple integer comparison
‚Ä¢ Timezone-safe - Always UTC-based
‚Ä¢ Compact storage - Just one number

seconds-vs-milliseconds.title: Seconds vs Milliseconds
seconds-vs-milliseconds.content:
Unix timestamps come in two formats:

‚Ä¢ Seconds (10 digits) - 1702339200
‚Ä¢ Milliseconds (13 digits) - 1702339200000

JavaScript uses milliseconds:
‚Ä¢ Date.now() returns milliseconds
‚Ä¢ new Date(timestamp) expects milliseconds

Most other systems use seconds. Always check which format your API expects!

how-to-use.title: How to Use This Tool
how-to-use.content:
Our converter supports bidirectional conversion:

1. Enter a Unix timestamp to see the human-readable date
2. Enter a date/time to get the Unix timestamp
3. View results in multiple formats and timezones
4. Copy the result with one click

The tool updates in real-time as you type.

timezone-handling.title: Timezone Handling
timezone-handling.content:
Unix timestamps are always in UTC, but display can vary:

‚Ä¢ UTC time - The universal standard
‚Ä¢ Local time - Converted to your timezone
‚Ä¢ Custom timezone - Specify any timezone

Key points:
‚Ä¢ Timestamp value never changes
‚Ä¢ Only the display format changes
‚Ä¢ Always store timestamps in UTC

common-use-cases.title: Common Use Cases
common-use-cases.content:
Unix timestamps are essential for:

‚Ä¢ Database records - Created/updated timestamps
‚Ä¢ API responses - Standard time format
‚Ä¢ Event scheduling - Compare times easily
‚Ä¢ Log files - Sort chronologically
‚Ä¢ Session management - Expiration times

The Y2038 problem: 32-bit systems will overflow on January 19, 2038. Modern 64-bit systems are safe.

Each component serves a specific purpose in identifying and locating resources on the web.

headline-analyzer.howToUse: Geben Sie Ihre √úberschrift ein. Erhalten Sie sofortige Bewertungen f√ºr emotionale Wirkung, Wortbalance und L√§nge. Sehen Sie Verbesserungsvorschl√§ge und vergleichen Sie mit hochperformanten √úberschriften.

faq.q: Was ist ein guter √úberschriften-Score?
faq.a: 70+ gilt als gut. 80+ ist ausgezeichnet. Fokussieren Sie auf emotionale W√∂rter und optimale L√§nge (6-8 W√∂rter, 50-60 Zeichen).

faq.q: Wie wichtig sind emotionale W√∂rter?
faq.a: Sehr wichtig f√ºr CTR. √úberschriften mit emotionalen Triggern erhalten bis zu 2x mehr Klicks in Studien.

faq.q: Soll ich Zahlen in √úberschriften verwenden?
faq.a: Ja, Zahlen erh√∂hen die CTR. Listicles (10 Wege...) und spezifische Daten schneiden oft besser ab als vage √úberschriften.

bg-remover.whatIs: BG Remover verwendet KI, um automatisch Hintergr√ºnde aus Bildern zu entfernen. Er ist perfekt f√ºr Produktfotos, Portr√§ts und die Erstellung transparenter PNGs f√ºr Design und E-Commerce.
bg-remover.howToUse: Laden Sie ein Bild hoch. Die KI erkennt und entfernt den Hintergrund automatisch. Verfeinern Sie bei Bedarf die Kanten. Laden Sie das Ergebnis als transparentes PNG oder mit einem neuen Hintergrund herunter.

faq.q: Wie genau ist die KI-Hintergrundentfernung?
faq.a: Die Genauigkeit ist hoch f√ºr klare Motive. Komplexe Szenen, √§hnliche Farben oder feine Details ben√∂tigen m√∂glicherweise manuelle Verfeinerung.

faq.q: Werden meine Bilder auf einen Server hochgeladen?
faq.a: Nein, die Verarbeitung erfolgt vollst√§ndig in Ihrem Browser mit WebGL/WebGPU. Ihre Bilder verlassen nie Ihr Ger√§t.

faq.q: Welche Aufl√∂sung wird unterst√ºtzt?
faq.a: Bis zu 4K-Bilder werden unterst√ºtzt. Gr√∂√üere Bilder werden f√ºr die Verarbeitung herunterskaliert, dann hochskaliert.

og-generator.whatIs: OG Image Generator erstellt Open Graph-Bilder f√ºr Social-Media-Vorschauen. Er hilft, konsistente, markenkonforme Vorschaubilder zu erstellen, wenn Ihre Links auf Twitter, Facebook und LinkedIn geteilt werden.
og-generator.howToUse: W√§hlen Sie eine Vorlage oder beginnen Sie bei Null. F√ºgen Sie Titel, Beschreibung und Branding hinzu. Passen Sie Farben, Schriftarten und Layout an. Exportieren Sie als PNG im optimalen 1200x630px-Format.

faq.q: Was ist die beste OG-Bildgr√∂√üe?
faq.a: 1200x630px ist der Standard f√ºr Facebook/LinkedIn. Twitter bevorzugt 1200x600px, wird aber 1200x630 gut zuschneiden.

faq.q: Wie sorge ich daf√ºr, dass mein Bild √ºberall erscheint?
faq.a: F√ºgen Sie og:image Meta-Tags hinzu. Verwenden Sie absolute URLs. Testen Sie mit den Debuggern von Facebook/Twitter/LinkedIn.

faq.q: Kann ich diese f√ºr verschiedene Seiten automatisieren?
faq.a: Ja, verwenden Sie die API oder Vorlagen, um OG-Bilder dynamisch basierend auf Seiteninhalten zu generieren.

base-converter.whatIs: Number Base Converter instantly converts numbers between binary, octal, decimal, and hexadecimal formats. Essential for programmers and computer science students.
base-converter.howToUse: Enter a number in any supported base (binary, octal, decimal, or hexadecimal). See instant conversions to all other bases with proper formatting.

faq.q: What number bases are supported?
faq.a: Binary (base 2), octal (base 8), decimal (base 10), and hexadecimal (base 16) are fully supported.

faq.q: Can I convert very large numbers?
faq.a: Yes, the converter handles numbers up to JavaScript's safe integer limits and provides accurate results.

url-parser.whatIs: URL Parser breaks down URLs into their components: protocol, host, path, query parameters, and fragment. Essential for debugging and understanding web addresses.
url-parser.howToUse: Paste a URL to see it parsed into components. Edit query parameters individually. Build new URLs by modifying any part.

faq.q: What URL components are shown?
faq.a: Protocol, host, port, path, query parameters, and hash fragment are all displayed.

faq.q: Can I edit and rebuild URLs?
faq.a: Yes. Modify any component and the tool will build the complete URL for you.

curl-builder.whatIs: cURL Builder creates cURL commands from HTTP request specifications. Perfect for API testing, debugging, and sharing request examples.
curl-builder.howToUse: Select the HTTP method, enter the URL, add headers and body as needed. Copy the generated cURL command or execute it directly.

faq.q: Can I import existing cURL commands?
faq.a: Yes. Paste a cURL command to parse it into the visual builder for editing.

faq.q: What body formats are supported?
faq.a: JSON, form data, raw text, and multipart file uploads are all supported.

svg-optimizer.whatIs: SVG Optimizer reduces SVG file sizes by removing unnecessary data, optimizing paths, and cleaning up markup while maintaining visual quality.
svg-optimizer.howToUse: Upload or paste your SVG code. See the optimized result with size reduction percentage. Download the optimized file or copy the code.

faq.q: How much can file sizes be reduced?
faq.a: Typically 30-70% reduction depending on the SVG complexity and editor that created it.

faq.q: Will optimization affect the SVG appearance?
faq.a: No. Optimization removes unnecessary data while preserving the visual output.

css-to-tailwind.whatIs: CSS to Tailwind converts standard CSS properties to Tailwind CSS utility classes. Speed up your migration to Tailwind or learn the equivalent classes.
css-to-tailwind.howToUse: Paste your CSS code in the input area. See the equivalent Tailwind classes generated. Copy individual classes or the complete conversion.

faq.q: Does it support all CSS properties?
faq.a: Most common properties are supported. Some complex or custom properties may not have direct Tailwind equivalents.

faq.q: Which Tailwind version is used?
faq.a: Tailwind CSS v3.x classes are generated by default.

prettier-playground.whatIs: Prettier Playground formats code in JavaScript, TypeScript, CSS, HTML, JSON, and more using the official Prettier formatter.
prettier-playground.howToUse: Paste your code, select the language, and see it formatted instantly. Customize Prettier options like tab width and quotes style.

faq.q: Which languages are supported?
faq.a: JavaScript, TypeScript, CSS, HTML, JSON, Markdown, YAML, and GraphQL are supported.

faq.q: Can I customize formatting rules?
faq.a: Yes. Configure tab width, semicolons, quotes, and other Prettier options.

box-shadow.whatIs: Box Shadow Generator creates CSS box-shadow effects with a visual editor. Design beautiful shadows and copy the CSS code directly.
box-shadow.howToUse: Adjust shadow offset, blur, spread, and color using sliders. See the live preview and copy the generated CSS code.

faq.q: Can I add multiple shadows?
faq.a: Yes. Layer multiple shadows to create complex depth effects.

faq.q: Is the CSS cross-browser compatible?
faq.a: Yes. The generated CSS works in all modern browsers without vendor prefixes.

gradient-generator.whatIs: Gradient Generator creates CSS linear and radial gradients with a visual editor. Design beautiful color transitions for your web projects.
gradient-generator.howToUse: Add color stops, adjust positions, and set gradient direction. See the live preview and copy CSS code for use in your stylesheets.

faq.q: Can I create radial gradients?
faq.a: Yes. Switch between linear and radial gradient types with full customization.

faq.q: How many colors can I use?
faq.a: Unlimited. Add as many color stops as needed to create complex gradients.

app-icon-generator.whatIs: App Icon Generator creates all required icon sizes for iOS, Android, and web favicons from a single image. Save hours of manual resizing.
app-icon-generator.howToUse: Upload your high-resolution icon (1024x1024 recommended). Select platforms and download a ZIP with all generated sizes.

faq.q: What image size should I upload?
faq.a: Use 1024x1024 pixels for best quality across all generated sizes.

faq.q: Which platforms are supported?
faq.a: iOS (all iPhone/iPad sizes), Android (mdpi to xxxhdpi), and web favicons.

ua-parser.whatIs: User Agent Parser analyzes browser user agent strings to extract browser name, version, operating system, and device information.
ua-parser.howToUse: Paste a user agent string or use your current browser's UA. See the parsed information including browser, OS, and device details.

faq.q: What information can be extracted?
faq.a: Browser name/version, OS name/version, device type, and whether it's a bot.

faq.q: Is user agent parsing reliable?
faq.a: Generally yes, but some browsers spoof UAs. Use for analytics, not security.

lorem-generator.whatIs: Lorem Ipsum Generator creates placeholder text for design mockups and development. Generate words, sentences, or paragraphs as needed.
lorem-generator.howToUse: Select the type (words, sentences, paragraphs) and quantity. Click generate to create placeholder text and copy to clipboard.

faq.q: What is Lorem Ipsum?
faq.a: It's placeholder text used in design since the 1500s, based on Latin literature.

faq.q: Why use Lorem Ipsum instead of real text?
faq.a: It helps focus on visual design without the distraction of readable content.

html-entity.whatIs: HTML Entity Encoder converts special characters to HTML entities and back. Prevent XSS attacks and display special characters correctly in web pages.
html-entity.howToUse: Enter text with special characters to encode, or paste HTML entities to decode. See the converted result and copy to use in your HTML.

faq.q: Why use HTML entities?
faq.a: To display characters like <, >, & correctly in HTML and prevent security issues.

faq.q: What's the difference between named and numeric?
faq.a: Named (&) is readable; numeric (&) works for any Unicode character.

json-to-typescript.whatIs: JSON to TypeScript converts JSON data to TypeScript interfaces or type definitions. Generate type-safe code from API responses instantly.
json-to-typescript.howToUse: Paste your JSON data and configure options like root name, interface vs type, and optional properties. Copy the generated TypeScript code.

faq.q: Should I use interface or type?
faq.a: Interfaces are preferred for objects as they can be extended. Types are better for unions and complex types.

faq.q: Does it handle nested JSON?
faq.a: Yes, nested objects are converted to separate interfaces/types automatically.

css-minifier.whatIs: CSS Minifier compresses CSS code by removing whitespace, comments, and optimizing syntax. Reduce file size for faster page loads.
css-minifier.howToUse: Paste your CSS code and click minify. Configure options like removing comments, shortening colors, and merging selectors. Copy or download the result.

faq.q: How much can file size be reduced?
faq.a: Typically 20-60% depending on the original CSS formatting and comments.

faq.q: Will minification break my CSS?
faq.a: No, minification only removes unnecessary characters while preserving functionality.

text-case-converter.whatIs: Text Case Converter transforms text between various naming conventions including camelCase, snake_case, kebab-case, and more.
text-case-converter.howToUse: Enter your text and see instant conversions to all supported cases. Click any result to copy it to your clipboard.

faq.q: What cases are supported?
faq.a: camelCase, PascalCase, snake_case, kebab-case, CONSTANT_CASE, and more.

faq.q: When should I use each case?
faq.a: camelCase for JavaScript variables, snake_case for Python, kebab-case for CSS classes and URLs.

video-compressor.whatIs: Video Compressor uses FFmpeg.wasm to compress video files directly in your browser. All processing happens 100% locally on your device.
video-compressor.howToUse: Upload a video file, select a quality preset, and click the compress button. Download the compressed file when ready.

faq.q: Is my video uploaded to a server?
faq.a: No, all processing happens in your browser and your files are never sent to any server.

faq.q: What formats are supported?
faq.a: MP4, WebM, MOV, AVI and other major video formats. Maximum file size is 500MB.

image-converter.whatIs: Image Converter transforms images between various formats including JPEG, PNG, WebP, AVIF, and GIF. All processing happens 100% in your browser with no server uploads.
image-converter.howToUse: Upload images by drag-and-drop or clicking the upload area. Select your desired output format and adjust quality settings. Convert and download individual images or all at once.
features: Support for JPEG, PNG, WebP, AVIF, and GIF formats
Adjustable quality settings for optimal file size

faq.q: Which format should I use?
faq.a: WebP offers the best balance of quality and file size for web. AVIF provides even better compression but has limited browser support. JPEG is ideal for photos, PNG for graphics with transparency.

faq.q: Is AVIF supported in my browser?
faq.a: AVIF is supported in Chrome 85+, Firefox 93+, and Safari 16+. The tool automatically detects and shows available formats for your browser.

sitemap-generator.whatIs: Sitemap Generator creates XML sitemaps for search engines. A sitemap helps search engines discover and index your website's pages more efficiently.
sitemap-generator.howToUse: Enter your website URLs (one per line or comma-separated). Configure options like change frequency and priority. Click Generate to create your sitemap.xml file.
features: Configurable change frequency (daily, weekly, monthly, etc.)
Pretty print option for readable XML

faq.q: What is a sitemap?
faq.a: A sitemap is an XML file that lists all important pages on your website. It helps search engines like Google discover and crawl your content more efficiently.

faq.q: How often should I update my sitemap?
faq.a: Update your sitemap whenever you add, remove, or significantly change pages. For dynamic sites, consider automated sitemap generation.

faq.q: Where should I put my sitemap?
faq.a: Place your sitemap.xml in your website's root directory (e.g., https://example.com/sitemap.xml) and reference it in your robots.txt file.

meta-tag-analyzer.whatIs: Meta Tag Analyzer examines your webpage's meta tags and provides SEO improvement suggestions. Check Open Graph, Twitter Card, and standard meta tags.
meta-tag-analyzer.howToUse: Enter a URL to analyze or paste your HTML code. The tool will extract and evaluate all meta tags, showing what's present, missing, and what can be improved.

faq.q: What are meta tags?
faq.a: Meta tags are HTML elements that provide information about your webpage to search engines and social media platforms.

robots-generator.whatIs: Robots.txt Generator creates robots.txt files that tell search engine crawlers which pages to access and which to avoid on your website.
robots-generator.howToUse: Add rules for different user agents (crawlers). Specify allowed and disallowed paths. Add your sitemap URL. Download the generated robots.txt file.
features: Common presets for major search engines

faq.q: What is robots.txt?
faq.a: Robots.txt is a text file that tells web crawlers which pages they can or cannot access on your site.

serp-preview.whatIs: SERP Preview shows how your webpage will appear in Google search results. Optimize your title, description, and URL for better click-through rates.
serp-preview.howToUse: Enter your page title, meta description, and URL. See a real-time preview of how it appears in desktop and mobile search results. Get optimization tips.

faq.q: What is SERP?
faq.a: SERP stands for Search Engine Results Page - the page you see after searching on Google or other search engines.

share-as-image.whatIs: Share as Image creates beautiful, shareable images of your code snippets. Like Carbon, it transforms your code into visually appealing graphics for social media, documentation, and presentations.
share-as-image.howToUse: Paste your code, choose a theme and background, customize the styling options, then download as PNG, JPEG, or SVG. You can also copy the image directly to clipboard.
features: 8 popular code themes (Dracula, Monokai, Night Owl, etc.)
Customizable font size, padding, and border radius
Export as PNG, JPEG, or SVG

faq.q: What is Share as Image?
faq.a: Share as Image is a tool that converts code snippets into beautiful, shareable images - similar to Carbon (carbon.now.sh) but integrated into your development workflow.

faq.q: What export formats are supported?
faq.a: You can export as PNG (best quality), JPEG (smaller file size), or SVG (scalable vector). PNG is recommended for most uses.

Find errors and missing fields faster

benefits: Catch syntax errors before they break your build
Easy to read deeply nested configurations
Real-time validation prevents typos

benefits: Instantly see token expiration and validity

Identify missing or malformed claims
Debug authentication issues faster
